template.name: Exchange 2016
template.description: ## Overview Converted the Exchange 2010 Performance Monitoring Templates. Removed unsupported items and replaced them with equivalents that could be found. Added some new items and graphs. ## Author matt snead

item.name: Exchange ActiveSync\Current Requests
item.description: Shows the number of HTTP requests waiting to be assigned to a thread

item.name: Exchange ADAccess Domain Controllers(*)\LDAP Read Calls/sec
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange ADAccess Domain Controllers(*)\LDAP Read Calls/sec"]
item.description: Shows the current rate that LDAP reads occur while processing requests for the client. Used to determine the current LDAP read rate per protocol. MODIFIED_FOR_EX2016-WAS:perf_counter["\MSExchangeIS Client(*)\Directory Access: LDAP Reads/sec"]

item.name: Exchange ADAccess Domain Controllers(*)\LDAP Read Time
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange ADAccess Domain Controllers(*)\LDAP Read Time"]

trigger.name: Exchange ADAccess Domain Controller LDAP Read Time

item.name: Exchange ADAccess Domain Controllers(*)\LDAP Search Time
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange ADAccess Domain Controllers(*)\LDAP Search Time"]

trigger.name: Exchange ADAccess Domain Controller LDAP Search Time

item.name: Exchange ADAccess Processes(*)\LDAP Read Time

trigger.name: Exchange ADAccess Processes LDAP Read Time

item.name: Exchange ADAccess Processes(*)\LDAP Search Time

trigger.name: Exchange ADAccess Processes LDAP Search Time

item.name: Exchange Mailbox Calendar Attendant Average Calendar Attendant Processing Time
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Calendar Attendant\Average Calendar Attendant Processing Time",30]
item.description: Shows the average time to process an event in the Calendar Attendant. Should be a low value at all times. High values may indicate a performance bottleneck.

item.name: Exchange Mailbox Database I/O Database Reads (Attached) Average Latency
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Database(*)\I/O Database Reads (Attached) Average Latency"]
item.description: Indicates the average time, in milliseconds (ms), to read from the database file. The average value should be below 20 ms. Spikes (maximum values) shouldn't be higher than 100 ms.

trigger.name: MSExchange Database(*)\I/O Database Reads (Attached) Average Latency
trigger.description: Indicates the average time, in milliseconds (ms), to read from the database file. The average value should be below 20 ms. Spikes (maximum values) shouldn't be higher than 100 ms.

trigger.name: MSExchange Database(*)\I/O Database Reads (Attached) Average Latency
trigger.description: Indicates the average time, in milliseconds (ms), to read from the database file. The average value should be below 20 ms. Spikes (maximum values) shouldn't be higher than 100 ms.

item.name: Exchange Mailbox Database I/O Database Reads (Recovery) Average Latency
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Database(*)\I/O Database Reads (Recovery) Average Latency"]
item.description: Indicates the average time, in ms, to read from the database file. The average value should be below 200 ms. Spikes (maximum values) shouldn't be higher than 1,000 ms.

trigger.name: MSExchange Database(*)\I/O Database Reads (Recovery) Average Latency
trigger.description: Indicates the average time, in ms, to read from the database file. The average value should be below 200 ms. Spikes (maximum values) shouldn't be higher than 1,000 ms.

trigger.name: MSExchange Database(*)\I/O Database Reads (Recovery) Average Latency
trigger.description: Indicates the average time, in ms, to read from the database file. The average value should be below 200 ms. Spikes (maximum values) shouldn't be higher than 1,000 ms.

item.name: Exchange Mailbox Database I/O Database Writes (Attached) Average Latency
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Database(*)\I/O Database Writes (Attached) Average Latency"]
item.description: Indicates the average time, in ms, to write to the database file. This counter isn't a good indicator for client latency because database writes are asynchronous. In general, this latency should be less than the MSExchange Database\I/O Database Reads (Attached) Average Latency when battery-backed write caching is utilized.

trigger.name: MSExchange Database(*)\I/O Database Writes (Attached) Average Latency
trigger.description: Indicates the average time, in ms, to write to the database file. This counter isn't a good indicator for client latency because database writes are asynchronous. In general, this latency should be less than the MSExchange Database\I/O Database Reads (Attached) Average Latency when battery-backed write caching is utilized.

trigger.name: MSExchange Database(*)\I/O Database Writes (Attached) Average Latency
trigger.description: Indicates the average time, in ms, to write to the database file. This counter isn't a good indicator for client latency because database writes are asynchronous. In general, this latency should be less than the MSExchange Database\I/O Database Reads (Attached) Average Latency when battery-backed write caching is utilized.

item.name: Exchange Mailbox Database I/O Database Writes (Recovery) Average Latency
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Database(*)\I/O Database Writes (Recovery) Average Latency"]
item.description: Indicates the average time, in ms, to write to the database file. In general, this latency should be less than the MSExchange Database\I/O Database Reads (Recovery) Average Latency when battery-backed write caching is utilized.

trigger.name: MSExchange Database(*)\I/O Database Writes (Recovery) Average Latency
trigger.description: Indicates the average time, in ms, to write to the database file. In general, this latency should be less than the MSExchange Database\I/O Database Reads (Recovery) Average Latency when battery-backed write caching is utilized.

trigger.name: MSExchange Database(*)\I/O Database Writes (Recovery) Average Latency
trigger.description: Indicates the average time, in ms, to write to the database file. In general, this latency should be less than the MSExchange Database\I/O Database Reads (Recovery) Average Latency when battery-backed write caching is utilized.

item.name: Exchange Mailbox Database I/O Log Reads Average Latency
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Database(*)\I/O Log Reads Average Latency"]
item.description: Indicates the average time, in ms, to read data from a log file. Specific to log replay and database recovery operations. The average value should be below 200 ms. Spikes (maximum values) shouldn't be higher than 1,000 ms.

trigger.name: MSExchange Database(*)\IO Log Read Average Latency
trigger.description: Indicates the average time, in ms, to read data from a log file. Specific to log replay and database recovery operations. The average value should be below 200 ms. Spikes (maximum values) shouldn't be higher than 1,000 ms.

trigger.name: MSExchange Database(*)\IO Log Read Average Latency
trigger.description: Indicates the average time, in ms, to read data from a log file. Specific to log replay and database recovery operations. The average value should be below 200 ms. Spikes (maximum values) shouldn't be higher than 1,000 ms.

item.name: Exchange Mailbox Database I/O Log Writes Average Latency
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Database(*)\I/O Log Writes Average Latency"]
item.description: Indicates the average time, in ms, to write a log buffer to the active log file. This counter should be 10 on production servers. If this counter is greater than 10, it's an indication that the MSExchange Database\I/O Database Writes (Attached) Average Latency is too high.

trigger.name: MSExchange Database(*)\IO Log Writes Average Latency
trigger.description: Indicates the average time, in ms, to write a log buffer to the active log file. This counter should be 10 on production servers. If this counter is greater than 10, it's an indication that the MSExchange Database\I/O Database Writes (Attached) Average Latency is too high.

item.name: Exchange Mailbox Database (Information Store) Database Cache % Hit
item.description: Shows the percentage of database file page requests fulfilled by the database cache without causing a file operation. If this percentage is too low, the database cache size may be too small. Should be over 90% for companies with majority online mode clients. Should be over 99% for companies with majority cached mode clients. If the hit ratio is less than these numbers, the database cache may be insufficient.

trigger.name: MSExchange Database(Information Store)\Database Cache % Hit
trigger.description: Shows the percentage of database file page requests fulfilled by the database cache without causing a file operation. If this percentage is too low, the database cache size may be too small. Should be over 90% for companies with majority online mode clients. Should be over 99% for companies with majority cached mode clients. If the hit ratio is less than these numbers, the database cache may be insufficient.

item.name: Exchange Mailbox Database (Information Store) Database Cache Size (GB)
item.description: Shows the amount of system memory, in megabytes (MB), used by the database cache manager to hold commonly used information from the database files to prevent file operations. Maximum value is RAM-2GB (RAM-3GB for servers with sync replication enabled). This and Database Cache Hit % are useful counters for gauging whether a server's performance problems might be resolved by adding more physical memory. Use this counter along with store private bytes to determine if there are store memory leaks. If the database cache size seems too small for optimal performance and there is little available memory on the system (check the value of Memory/Available Bytes), adding more memory to the system may increase performance. If there is ample memory on the system and the database cache size isn't growing beyond a certain point, the database cache size may be capped at an artificially low limit. Increasing this limit may increase performance.

trigger.name: MSExchange Database(Information Store)\Database Cache Size
trigger.description: Shows the amount of system memory, in megabytes (MB), used by the database cache manager to hold commonly used information from the database files to prevent file operations. Maximum value is RAM-2GB (RAM-3GB for servers with sync replication enabled). This and Database Cache Hit % are useful counters for gauging whether a server's performance problems might be resolved by adding more physical memory. Use this counter along with store private bytes to determine if there are store memory leaks. If the database cache size seems too small for optimal performance and there is little available memory on the system (check the value of Memory/Available Bytes), adding more memory to the system may increase performance. If there is ample memory on the system and the database cache size isn't growing beyond a certain point, the database cache size may be capped at an artificially low limit. Increasing this limit may increase performance.

item.name: Exchange Mailbox Database (Information Store) Database Page Fault Stalls/sec
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Database(Information Store)\Database Page Fault Stalls/sec"]
item.description: Shows the rate that database file page requests require of the database cache manager to allocate a new page from the database cache. If this value is nonzero, this indicates that the database isn't able to flush dirty pages to the database file fast enough to make pages free for new page allocations.

trigger.name: MSExchange Database(Information Store)\Database Page Fault Stalls/sec
trigger.description: Shows the rate that database file page requests require of the database cache manager to allocate a new page from the database cache. If this value is nonzero, this indicates that the database isn't able to flush dirty pages to the database file fast enough to make pages free for new page allocations.

item.name: Exchange Mailbox Database (Information Store) Version buckets allocated
item.description: Shows the total number of version buckets allocated. Should be less than 12,000 at all times. The maximum default version is 16,384. If version buckets reach 70% of maximum, the server is at risk of running out of the version store.

trigger.name: MSExchange Database(Information Store)\Version buckets allocated
trigger.description: Shows the total number of version buckets allocated. Should be less than 12,000 at all times. The maximum default version is 16,384. If version buckets reach 70% of maximum, the server is at risk of running out of the version store.

item.name: Exchange Mailbox Database ==> Instances(*) Log Generation Checkpoint Depth
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\Log Generation Checkpoint Depth"]
item.description: Represents the amount of work in the log file count that needs to be redone or undone to the database files if the process fails. Should be below 500 at all times for the Mailbox server role. A healthy server should indicate between 20 and 30 for each database instance. If checkpoint depth increases continually for a sustained period, this indicates either a long-running transaction, (which will impact the version store), or a bottleneck involving the database disks.

trigger.name: MSExchange Database ==> Instances(*)\Log Generation Checkpoint Depth
trigger.description: Represents the amount of work in the log file count that needs to be redone or undone to the database files if the process fails. Should be below 500 at all times for the Mailbox server role. A healthy server should indicate between 20 and 30 for each database instance. If checkpoint depth increases continually for a sustained period, this indicates either a long-running transaction, (which will impact the version store), or a bottleneck involving the database disks. MODIFIED_FOR_EX2016-WAS:500 ... per: https://thoughtsofanidlemind.com/2013/03/15/exchange-2013-log-truncation/

item.name: Exchange Transport Database ==> Instances(edgetransport/Transport Mail Database) I/O Database Reads/sec
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Database ==> Instances(edgetransport/Transport Mail Database)\I/O Database Reads/sec"]

item.name: Exchange Transport Database ==> Instances(edgetransport/Transport Mail Database) I/O Database Writes/sec
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Database ==> Instances(edgetransport/Transport Mail Database)\I/O Database Writes/sec"]

item.name: Exchange Transport Database ==> Instances(edgetransport/Transport Mail Database) I/O Log Reads/sec
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Database ==> Instances(edgetransport/Transport Mail Database)\I/O Log Reads/sec"]

item.name: Exchange Transport Database ==> Instances(edgetransport/Transport Mail Database) I/O Log Writes/sec
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Database ==> Instances(edgetransport/Transport Mail Database)\I/O Log Writes/sec"]

item.name: Exchange Transport Database ==> Instances(edgetransport/Transport Mail Database) Log Generation Checkpoint Depth
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Database ==> Instances(edgetransport/Transport Mail Database)\Log Generation Checkpoint Depth"]
item.description: Represents the amount of work (in count of log files) that needs to be redone or undone to the database files if the process fails.

item.name: Exchange Mailbox IS Client(*) Directory Access: LDAP Searches/sec
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchangeIS Client Type(*)\Directory Access: LDAP Searches/sec"]
item.description: Shows the current rate that LDAP searches occur while processing requests for the client. Used to determine the current LDAP search rate per protocol. MODIFIED_FOR_EX2016-WAS:perf_counter["\MSExchangeIS Client(*)\Directory Access: LDAP Searches/sec"]

item.name: Exchange Mailbox IS Client(*) JET Log Records/sec
item.description: Shows the rate that database log records are generated while processing requests for the client. Used to determine current load.

item.name: Exchange Mailbox IS Client(*) JET Pages Read/sec
item.description: Shows the rate that database pages are read from disk while processing requests for the client. Used to determine current load.

item.name: ExchangeIS Client Type(*)\RPC Average Latency

trigger.name: MSExchangeIS Client Type(*)\RPC Average Latency

item.name: Exchange Mailbox IS Client(*) RPC Operations/sec
item.description: Shows what client protocol is performing an excessive amount of RPC Operations/sec. High IMAP4, POP3, or Outlook Anywhere latency can indicate problems with Client Access servers rather than Mailbox servers. This is especially true when other clients (which includes MAPI) latency is lower in comparison. In some instances, high IMAP latencies could indicate a bottleneck on the Mailbox server in addition to the latencies that the Client Access server is experiencing.

item.name: ExchangeIS Client Type\RPC Requests

trigger.name: MSExchangeIS Client Type\RPC Requests

item.name: ExchangeIS Store(*)\RPC Average Latency

trigger.name: MSExchangeIS Store(*)\RPC Average Latency

item.name: Exchange Mailbox IS RPC Operations/sec
item.description: Indicates the current number of RPC operations occurring per second. Should closely correspond to historical baselines. Values much higher than expected indicate that the workload has changed, while values much lower than expected indicate a bottleneck preventing client requests from reaching the server. MODIFIED_FOR_EX2016-WAS:perf_counter["\MSExchangeIS\RPC Operations/sec"]

item.name: Exchange Mailbox IS Mailbox(*) Search Rate
item.description: Shows the number of search tasks created per second. Should be less than 10 at all times. MODIFIED_FOR_EX2016-WAS:perf_counter["\MSExchangeIS Mailbox(*)\Search Task Rate"]

trigger.name: MSExchangeIS Mailbox(*)\Search Task Rate
trigger.description: Shows the number of search tasks created per second. Should be less than 10 at all times.

item.name: Exchange Outlook (MapiHttp) User Count
item.description: Shows the number of users connected to the information store. Used to determine current user load. MODIFIED_FOR_EX2016-NEW

item.name: Exchange Middle-Tier Storage(*)\Items Dumpster Deletions/sec
item.description: Shows the rate at which items are deleted from the transport dumpster on this server. Determines the current rate of transport dumpster deletions. MODIFIED_FOR_EX2016-WAS:perf_counter["\MSExchangeTransport Dumpster\Dumpster Deletes/sec"]

item.name: Exchange Middle-Tier Storage(*)\Items Moved to Dumpster/sec
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Middle-Tier Storage(*)\Items Moved to Dumpster/sec."]
item.description: Shows the rate at which items are inserted into the transport dumpster on this server. Determines the current rate of transport dumpster inserts. MODIFIED_FOR_EX2016-WAS:perf_counter["\MSExchangeTransport Dumpster\Dumpster Inserts/sec"]

item.name: Exchange OWA User Count
item.description: Shows the number of users connected to the information store. Used to determine current user load. MODIFIED_FOR_EX2016-WAS:perf_counter["\MSExchangeIS\User Count"]

item.name: Exchange Mailbox Replication(*) CopyQueueLength
item.description: Shows the number of transaction log files waiting to be copied to the passive copy log file folder. A copy isn't considered complete until it has been checked for corruption. Should be less than 1 at all times for continuous replication.

trigger.name: MSExchange Replication(*)\CopyQueueLength
trigger.description: Shows the number of transaction log files waiting to be copied to the passive copy log file folder. A copy isn't considered complete until it has been checked for corruption. Should be less than 1 at all times for continuous replication.

item.name: Exchange Mailbox Replication(*) ReplayQueueLength
item.description: Shows the number of transaction log files waiting to be replayed into the passive copy. Indicates the current replay queue length. Higher values cause longer store mount times when a handoff, failover, or activation is performed.

item.name: Exchange Mailbox Resource Booking Average Resource Booking Processing Time
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Resource Booking\Average Resource Booking Processing Time"]
item.description: Shows the average time to process an event in the Resource Booking Attendant. Should be a low value at all times. High values may indicate a performance bottleneck.

item.name: Exchange RpcClientAccess Active User Count
item.description: Shows the number of users connected to the information store. Used to determine current user load. MODIFIED_FOR_EX2016-NEW

item.name: Exchange RpcClientAccess Connection Count
item.description: Shows the total number of client connections maintained

item.name: Exchange RpcClientAccess\RPC Averaged Latency
item.description: Shows the average latency, in ms, of the most recent RPCs to the Information Store service. These RPCs are used to get content for the filter daemon for the specified database. Should coincide with the latencies that Outlook clients are experiencing. MODIFIED_FOR_EX2016-WAS:perf_counter["\MSExchange Search Indices(*)\Average Latency of RPCs Used to Obtain Content"]

trigger.name: MSExchange RpcClientAccess\RPC Averaged Latency
trigger.description: MODIFIED_FOR_EX2016-NEW

item.name: Exchange RpcClientAccess\RPC Requests

trigger.name: MSExchange RpcClientAccess\RPC Requests

item.name: Exchange Search Indexes(*)\Crawler: Mailboxes Remaining
item.description: This counter is used to determine if a full crawl is occurring for any specified database. MODIFIED_FOR_EX2016-WAS:perf_counter["\MSExchange Search Indices(*)\Full Crawl Mode Status"] If CPU resources are high, it's possible content indexing is occurring for a database or set of databases.

item.name: ExchangeSearch Indexes(*)\Items Processed/sec
item.description: Shows the average, in ms, of how long it takes to index documents. MODIFIED_FOR_EX2016-WAS:perf_counter["\MSExchange Search Indices(*)\Average Document Indexing Time"]

item.name: Exchange Mailbox Store Interface(*) ROP Requests outstanding
item.description: Shows the total number of outstanding remote operations requests. Used for determining current load.

item.name: Exchange Mailbox Store Interface(*) RPC Requests Outstanding
item.description: Shows the total number of outstanding RPC requests. Used for determining current load.

item.name: Exchange Mailbox Store Interface(*) RPC Slow Requests latency average (msec)
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Store Interface(*)\RPC Slow Requests latency average (msec)"]
item.description: Shows the average latency, in ms, of slow requests. Used for determining the average latencies of RPC slow requests.

item.name: Exchange Mailbox Store Interface(_Total) RPC Requests outstanding
item.description: Shows the current number of outstanding RPC requests. Should be 0 at all times.

trigger.name: MSExchange Store Interface(_Total)\RPC Requests outstanding
trigger.description: Shows the current number of outstanding RPC requests. Should be 0 at all times.

item.name: Exchange Submission Successful Submissions Per Second
item.description: Determines current mail submission rate. MODIFIED_FOR_EX2016-WAS:perf_counter["\MSExchange Mail Submission(*)\Successful Submissions Per Second"]

item.name: Exchange Transport Q - Mailbox Delivery Q
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchangeTransport Queues(_total)\Active Mailbox Delivery Queue Length"]
item.description: This monitor shows the number of messages in the active mailbox queues. The returned value should be less than 250 at all times

trigger.name: Mailbox Delivery Queue
trigger.description: Shows the number of messages in the active mailbox queues. Should be less than 250 at all times.

item.name: Exchange Transport Q - Remote Delivery Q
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchangeTransport Queues(_total)\External Active Remote Delivery Queue Length"]
item.description: MODIFIED_FOR_EX2016-WAS:perf_counter["\MSExchangeTransport Queues(_total)\Active Remote Delivery Queue Length"]

item.name: Exchange Transport Q - Msgs Completed Delivery/sec
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchangeTransport Queues(_total)\Messages Completed Delivery Per Second"]
item.description: Shows the number of messages delivered per second. Determines current load. Compare values to historical baselines.

item.name: Exchange Transport Q - Msgs Queued For Delivery
item.description: MODIFIED_FOR_EX2016-WAS:perf_counter["\MSExchangeTransport Queues(_total)\Aggregate Delivery Queue Length (All Queues)"]

trigger.name: Messages in Queue
trigger.description: Shows the number of messages queued for delivery in all queues. Should be less than 3,000 and not more than 5,000.

item.name: Exchange Transport Q - Msgs Queued for Delivery/sec
item.key: perf_counter["\MSExchangeTransport Queues(_total)\Messages Queued for Delivery Per Second"]
item.description: Shows the number of messages queued for delivery per second. Determines current load. Compare values to historical baselines.

item.name: Exchange Transport Q - Msgs Submitted/sec
Exchange Transport Q - Submission Q
item.description: This monitor shows the number of messages in the submission queue. The returned value should not exceed 100. If sustained high values are occurring, investigate Active Directory and Mailbox servers for bottlenecks or performance-related issues. MODIFIED_FOR_EX2016-NEW

trigger.name: ExchangeTransport Submission Queue Length
trigger.description: This monitor shows the number of messages in the submission queue. The returned value should not exceed 100. If sustained high values are occurring, investigate Active Directory and Mailbox servers for bottlenecks or performance-related issues.

item.name: Exchange Transport SmtpReceive(_total) Messages Received/sec
item.description: Shows the number of messages received by the SMTP server each second. Determines current load. Compare values to historical baselines.

item.name: Exchange Transport SmtpSend(_total) Messages Sent/sec
item.description: Shows the number of messages sent by the SMTP send connector each second. Determines current load. Compare values to historical baselines.

item.name: Exchange Mailbox Process(MSExchangeMailboxAssistants) % Processor Time
item.description: Shows the amount of processor time being consumed by mailbox assistants. Should be less than 5% of overall CPU capacity.

trigger.name: Process(MSExchangeMailboxAssistants)\%Processor Time
trigger.description: Shows the amount of processor time being consumed by mailbox assistants. Should be less than 5% of overall CPU capacity.

item.name: Exchange RPC/HTTP Proxy\Current Number of Unique Users
item.key: perf_counter["\RPC/HTTP Proxy\Current Number of Unique Users"]
item.description: Shows the number of unique users currently connected to a back-end server via RPC/HTTP
